item.title: Covid-19: UK 'confident' of second vaccine doses within 12 weeks
item.description: Asked about concerns over vaccine supply, the culture secretary says the timetable is on track.

item.title: Covid: Another lockdown 'last thing in world' that government wants
item.description: The lockdown easing plan is on track, says a government minister - but dates could be delayed.

item.title: Myanmar coup: Generals celebrated amid global fury over massacre
item.description: As the US condemned their "reign of terror", the coup leaders held an Armed Forces Day celebration.

item.title: MP Neale Hanvey defects from SNP to new Alba Party
item.description: Neale Hanvey, MP for Kirkcaldy and Cowdenbeath, follows Kenny MacAskill in joining Alex Salmond's new party.

item.title: Ben Cabango and Rabbi Matondo: Police investigate racist abuse on social media
item.description: Police are investigating after Wales players Ben Cabango and Rabbi Matondo are racially abused on social media.

item.title: Covid: Vaccine passports could help reopen society - Dowden
item.description: They could be used to help theatres and sports stadiums reopen, says the culture secretary.

item.title: Covid: Lorry drivers arriving in England to be tested
item.description: Hauliers, cabin crew and prison escorts entering the UK will need to take a Covid test from 6 April.

item.title: Hunt for remand prisoner mistakenly released in London
item.description: William Fernandez was being held on remand at HMP Wormwood Scrubs ahead of his trial.

item.title: Covid: Boris Johnson urged to share vaccines with poorer nations
item.description: A group of charities is calling on Boris Johnson to begin donating vaccines through the Covax scheme.

item.title: Max Woosey tent camp-out sees 1,000 children take part
item.description: Max Woosey has raised more than £500,000 for charity by sleeping in a tent for a whole year.

item.title: Walsall boy, 6, finds '488-million-year-old' fossil in garden
item.description: The schoolboy was "digging for worms" when he came across the fossil, which dates back millions of years.

item.title: ICYMI: Hotdogs, hungry horses and orange skies
item.description: See volcanic fast food and other stories in our weekly video round up: In Case You Missed It.

item.title: Meet the Aussie skateboarding 4,000km
item.description: Gordy says he is skating from Melbourne to Cairns but says he "didn't realise how big Australia was".

item.title: Project 17: The photograph that united a family
item.description: A photograph of a "burner boy" working on a toxic dump in Ghana helped his family to find him.

item.title: Your pictures on the theme of 'sculpture'
item.description: A selection of striking images from our readers on this week's theme.

item.title: How the 'world's worst sniffer dog' is helping the NHS
item.description: Dexter used to work as a sniffer dog for the Met but he was "too sociable" for the job.

item.title: Keeping Parliament clean in a pandemic
item.description: The team making sure the Palace of Westminster is spick and span describes a year like no other.

item.title: Jedward shave off their famous quiffs for cancer charity
item.description: The Irish twins removed each other's quiffs live on TV in memory of their late mother.

item.title: The women of Egypt's Arab Spring
item.description: Ten years ago, Egyptians took to the streets calling for the overthrow of President Hosni Mubarak

item.title: The visual effects challenge of Snyder’s Justice League
item.description: Two Weta Digital experts explain how they updated the characters' look.

item.title: Pembrokeshire walrus seen 'basking in sun' in Tenby
item.description: From North Pole to Pembrokeshire, a walrus seems to be continuing his trip around the Welsh coast.

item.title: Cambridge University: Butterfly found pressed inside centuries-old book
item.description: A university says a butterfly found in a book could be hundreds of years old.

item.title: Derek Chauvin trial: Why role of TV cameras could come into focus
item.description: Cameras will be in court, thanks to the network behind OJ Simpson’s trial. What role will they play?

item.title: Covid: What's happened to crime during the pandemic?
item.description: From dog theft to drug crime, lockdown has led to some big changes in policing.

item.title: Black Power: A British story of resistance told through music
item.description: This time, the revolution is being televised, but it was music that gave Black Power a timeless platform.

item.title: AI: Ghost workers demand to be seen and heard
item.description: Workers who label content and help computers understand language want their own voices to be heard.

item.title: The real reason humans are the dominant species
item.description: How demand for energy has been central to the development of humanity.

item.title: The lost letters that found New York drag scene's secret trailblazers
item.description: The film PS Burn This Letter Please tells untold stories from the lives of 1950s drag artists.

item.title: 'My pet has helped me so much during the pandemic'
item.description: Research has shown pets can have a huge benefit to our mental health - especially this past year.

item.title: The vaccine misinformation battle raging in France
item.description: Online conspiracy theories are exacerbating existing vaccine scepticism.

item.title: Suez Canal: How are they trying to free the Ever Given?
item.description: Operations are continuing to move a giant container vessel stuck in the Suez Canal since Tuesday.

item.title: 'Why risk-taker Whyte should live with being boring for a while'
item.description: Dillian Whyte remains a heavyweight threat - but what should he do with no world title shot on offer?

item.title: Republic of Ireland defeat by Luxembourg 'horrible & embarrassing' - Coleman
item.description: Seamus Coleman describes the Republic of Ireland's 1-0 World Cup qualifier defeat by Luxembourg as a "horrible and embarrassing night".

item.title: Why are Red Bull on top? Bahrain GP all you need to know
item.description: It's been a long time coming, but finally Mercedes appear to have a real challenge on their hands. And all because of a rake...

item.title: Ngannou knocks out Miocic at UFC 260 to capture heavyweight title
item.description: Francis Ngannou knocks out Stipe Miocic in the second round to capture the undisputed UFC heavyweight title in Las Vegas at UFC 260.

item.title: Covid: What is the rule of six and what are the social distancing rules?
item.description: Lockdown rules are being eased further in England and Wales so more people can meet up outside.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Wales and Scotland are easing restrictions on people meeting, and changes are due in England on Monday.

item.title: Covid passports: What are different countries planning?
item.description: How advanced are some countries' plans for vaccine certificates and Covid passports?

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 29 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People aged 50 and over are urged to book their Covid vaccine in the next few days.

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: Anyone in England who travels abroad without good reason will soon face a £5000 fine.

item.title: Which countries are on the red list and what are the quarantine rules?
item.description: Many travellers are no longer allowed to enter the UK from countries on the "red list".

item.title: Where is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine made?
item.description: The EU has called on AstraZeneca to "catch up" on its deliveries to the EU.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the R number and how is it calculated?
item.description: The R number is a simple but crucial figure at the heart of lockdown decisions across the UK.

item.title: Covid rules: What is the rule of six in England?
item.description: The rule of six is back for England from Monday but with some changes - we explain what they are.

item.title: Does the Oxford vaccine have a blood clot problem? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about England's roadmap out of lockdown, and other Covid-related issues.

item.title: Will I need a vaccine passport to go to the pub or travel abroad?
item.description: A government review is considering whether people will need to prove they have been vaccinated.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Covid: What’s the problem with the EU vaccine rollout?
item.description: The coronavirus vaccine is being rolled out across the EU but there have been delays.

item.title: India coronavirus: Why have vaccine exports been suspended?
item.description: India is a big player in vaccine production - but companies are warning of supply problems.

item.title: Covid vaccine: Side effects and why it can’t give you the virus
item.description: It's normal to experience some mild side effects, such as a headache or a raised temperature.

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Covid: How are European countries tackling the pandemic?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Unemployment rate: How many people are out of work?
item.description: The unemployment rate is rising as Covid hits different parts of the economy.

item.title: Covid: The inside story of the government's battle against the virus
item.description: Twenty of Downing Street's most senior politicians, officials and former officials take you "into the room" where essential Covid decisions were being made.

item.title: Covid: The countries that nailed it, and what we can learn from them
item.description: A year into the pandemic, we look at countries that have had some success in tackling the virus.

item.title: Coronavirus: Your tributes to those who have died
item.description: A collection of your tributes to some of the thousands of people in the UK who have died with coronavirus.

item.title: Covid: What is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine?
item.description: The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccines should save many lives, say experts.

item.title: Coronavirus: Where does the government borrow billions from?
item.description: How does it work when a government wants to borrow money, and when does it have to pay it back?

item.title: Covid: More walking and family chats post-lockdown - poll suggests
item.description: We've done more walking and worked more from home this year, according to a BBC-commissioned poll.

item.title: Covid-19: Have a million people left the UK?
item.description: How far has the UK's foreign-born population fallen during the coronavirus pandemic?

item.title: Simon McCoy to leave BBC News after 17 years
item.description: The TV news presenter, known for his funny asides, is to join Andrew Neil's new GB News operation.

item.title: The Dig: Lego version of Sutton Hoo treasure 'amazing'
item.description: A father and daughter are told their Lego tribute is good enough to be put on display.

item.title: Bionic lamb walks again thanks to new wheels
item.description: Steven lost the use of his legs shortly after his birth. Until his owner modified a dog wheelchair.

item.title: Newcastle Racecourse sees more drones used by punters
item.description: Locals complain Covid travel rules are being broken, but flying drones is not illegal, police say.

item.title: Penzance couple still dancing and playing through pandemic
item.description: Sally and Ken Gilmour recently celebrated their 60th wedding anniversary.
